Introducing multiple managers would mean that we need atleast GetPLDMTypes to be issued to the EID before each manager starts a discovery process.
Agree, can't assume all types are supported.

My original idea was that each manager should check if EID supports expected PLDM Types and PLDM Commands by itself. It can make a simpler code structure but waste some bandwidth to send duplicated GetPLDMTypes and GetPLDMCommands by each managers.

Yeah we will need a discovery manager that does the base specifications command like TID management, invoke appropriate managers etc. That would mean only one time GetPLDMTypes and GetPLDMCommands will be issued.

Till we get to that point, i am okie with managers doing the check.

As my understanding the purpose of this patches is support static EID table.
The mctp_endpoint_discovery is a dynamic mechanism to add/remove the PLDM devices base on the MCTP devices in the MCTP D-Bus interface. It is not reasonable to add static EID solution in mctp_endpoint_discovery. fw-update/manager is concern fw-update so we should not change it also.

What do you think if we add device manager interface which is similar as manager of fw-update interface? This interface will manager all of EID in MCTP D-Bus interface and also static EID if need. You can load static_eid_table.json when construct Device manager interface.

I created patches to support device manager interface and device handler in below patches:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51246
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51245
Got it. Can we remove the terminus in the static EID table when the devices are off or unplug?

Sorry for late response. As the name suggests, I think the terminus defined by static EID table should always present in system. So when pldmd supports hot plug terminus, the static EID list would need to be merged into the dynamic EID list from /xyz/openbmc_project/mctp D-Bus interface.

Not all endpoint may/may not support all the handlers. Like, say endpoint X supports PLDM FWUP but not M&C. In that case, we need to identify that as part of discovery using GetPLDMTypes and invoke PLDM handlers accordingly.

Identifying the supported PLDM message type is done by the each handler for now per the discussion https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pldm/+/51184/comment/a666041e_a168ce2c/

Yes, the current design should be improved to avoid redundant discovery performed by each handler.

Can you state what testing was done for this patch and in general add that to all patches in this chain?

This patch is belong to a series of patch sets to create the PLDM sensors from the PLDM sensor PDRs. This patch will handle added/removeedInterface in MCTP Endpoint D-Bus signal to detect the appearing/deleting of MCTP endpoint. So for this patch we can only testing by add the debug message in code, make sure the handle methods is called correctly base on added/removeedInterface signal.

The test APIs is also added to verify the correction of the code.
Minor comments, looks good.

can this some how be put inside the environment file that pldm consumes & loads when it starts ? instead of having yet another configuration file ? or can we just have one common configuration file for pldm in which we add all the configuration settings 

My motive behind this question is that , having one common configuration file would allow us to do things like graceful reload of settings without actually restarting pldm.
On the flip side, a single config file would require all users of it to be aware to a certain extent of features they don't care about...

PLDM requester as BMC will not be interested in the configuration files of BMC as PLDM responder. 

Also static_eid_table_path is an optional config and the preferred way is for pldmd to be driven by MCTPEndpoint interface.

> On the flip side, a single config file would require all users of it to be aware to a certain extent of features they don't care about...

I dont understand why they have to be aware ..can you explain more ? i was thinking more like a toml config file where we have sections like [Requester], [Responder] e.t.c in a single configuration file. And get them parsed and converted to config data and code can decide what they need to look for based on the config information.

I see a lot of beginners in discord being confused on what files are needed/not needed to get thier pldm stack working, just a thought that a single configuration file would reduce confusion.
Again i am not trying to ask if this can be done in this commit, so this is not a hard stop on this commit. We can go-ahead and merge this commit if maintainers are okay.

I think a common yaml/json goes against the principle of separation of concerns.

The JSONs for example is well organized in libpldmresponder.

pldm/libpldmresponder/examples/bios
pldm/libpldmresponder/examples/effecter
..
..
..


Agree that beginners are finding it hard to get started and that is because we are missing out on good documentation. "Getting Started" documentation can cover dependencies with other OpenBMC apps, build configs, json details etc.
Ack
On interfacesRemoved we need to cleanup instead of discoverEndpoints?

According to current design of the MctpDiscovery class, there is nothing to cleanup so the action to handle Added/Removed signal for callback function is the same. MctpDiscovery just update the latest MCTP endpoint list to handlers.

It should make sense that cleanup actions be preformed by the mangers handler(e.g. fw-update, platform-mc) which has used the Endpoint information to instantiate class object.
We can add action for interfacesRemoved as a separate patch to handle cleanup by fw-update, platform-mc.
I agree with Tom Joseph.

The messages of interfaceAdded and interfaceRemoved signal is difference. They should be handled by two difference functions, I think.

The currently implementation treats the interfaceAdded and InterfaceRemoved signal like a event that the MCTP topology has been changed and then MCTPDiscovery passes the latest MCTP Endpoint list to each manager handlers(e.g. fw-update, platform-mc).

This design thinking makes the manager handlers(fw-update, platform-mc) don't need to added additional callback function for Removed signals and MCTPDiscovery also doesn't need to cache previous MCTP endpoint list to compare the latest list to find out which endpoint is removed because each handlers should already maintain a EID list which is managed by them currently.

Please let me know if this design fits your requirement.
Done

In case of single mctp network, it can happen only due to some invalid configuration and it will be a good addition to check for duplicates while emplacing elements to mctpInfos.

We faced a issue that PLDMD would have chance to report this error message when it started at first time and PLDMD didn't discover MCTP EID even though there was already a MCTP EID device listed in `xyz.openbmc_project.MCTP` service.

If we restart PLDMD or MCTPD again, PLDMD could detect the EID.

Would like to ask if there is any suggestion about this issue?

I think probably because MCTP service would have started after pldm service would have started. In that case we would end up with an exception.

We need to check for interfaces added signal if we get this except and read the EID's from the signal rather than just relying on the MCTP service to be present before pldm.

If the "NetworkId" type is "uint32_t", "std::get<>()" will generate the error "std::get: invalid index for variant" in "getMctpInfos()" and "getAddedMctpInfos()" (at least I personally had this problem).
You have to use `std::get<3>(mctpinfo)` or `std::get<NetworkId>(mctpinfo)` or `std::get<uint32_t>(mctpinfo)', I think.

Type of `123` and `123u` is different. `std::get<NetworkId>` need the `val` type should be uint32_t. Please check the type of `networkId` property in your mctp interface.
```
xyz.openbmc_project.MCTP.Endpoint   interface -         -                                      -
.EID                                property  y         8                                      const
.NetworkId                          property  u         1                                      const
.SupportedMessageTypes              property  ay        1 0                                    const
```

should we not remove the eid value from the eid vector created?

We should. When the EID Object Path of one Endpoint is removed from the MCTP D-Bus interfaces, that means that endpoint is not available in the MCTP network. The Endpoint handlers (terminus handler, sensor handler...) of that endpoint in `pldmd` should be removed.

The tests written are good, but these tests are not enough , we need to add tests to test all the functions that are written. we could mock the dbus calls to MCTP and return dummy data & verify if the functions that are written are supposedly doing what they are supposed to do.

The added functions and codes is tested with real Ampere with below case:
1. New MCTP Endpoint is added in the MCTP D_Bus interface.
2. One of two MCTP Endpoint is removed from the MCTP D_Bus interface.
3. Both MCTP Endpoints D-Bus object paths are removed.
4. Restart `pldmd` service when there are two MCTP Endpoints D-Bus object paths.
The functional of mctp-endpoint-discovery code worked as expected.

I knew that adding the software testing is good but I think the real test in the real system can be acceptable.
And DelphineCCChiu from Wiwynn also tested the code.

> I knew that adding the software testing is good but I think the real test in the real system can be acceptable.

I understand that it is tested good with hardware, but not every one will have the necessary hardware infrastructure to test this code, Unit tests are a way to get confidence on how the code works. We cannot always go by words on people saying "I have tested this , and it works on my platform". With the number of patch-sets in this commit & and the churn & contribution from various people in this commit,i would feel a bit more confident if we have the code unit tests improved. It helps will maintainability.


contributing document also states that same : https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
```
Commits which include changes that can be tested by a unit test should also include a unit test to exercise that change, within the same commit. Unit tests should be clearly written - even more so than production code, unit tests are meant primarily to be read by humans - and should test both good and bad behaviors.
```

I added the test case for `removeFromExistingMctpInfos`, `getMctpInfos`, `addToExistingMctpInfos` and `removeEndpoints`.
Because those functional is `private` to test them I have to change them to public.
